citations.narrative:
The facility did not submit their fiscal year 2024 annual report to the Deputy Administrator on or before December 1 of
calendar year 2024. At the time of inspection, the facility’s annual report had not yet been submitted. Timely submission of
the annual report is essential to assure that professionally acceptable standards governing the care and use of animals
were followed during the previous fiscal year. Each reporting facility shall submit an annual report, covering the use of live
animals in the previous fiscal year, on or before December 1st of each calendar year. Correct by March 7, 2025.

The facility does not currently have a regular cleaning schedule for the food receptacles for their rabbits. The husbandry
staff at the facility stated that there is no set schedule for the cleaning of the food receptacles, and that currently, the only
time they are cleaned is when a new rabbit is put into a new cage. Unsanitary food receptacles can contaminate the food
provided, and result in illness and disease in rabbits. All food receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitized at least once
every 2 weeks. Correct by March 7, 2025.

The facility does not currently have a regular sanitization schedule for the primary enclosures for their rabbits. The rabbits
are housed in mesh metal enclosures that are elevated above a trough used for urine and fecal waste removal. The
husbandry staff stated that while the troughs are cleaned thoroughly once per day, the primary enclosures for the rabbits
are only hosed down with water whenever they appear extra dirty. The husbandry staff stated that the hose does not
output hot water. At the time of inspection, husbandry staff were not trained on sanitization methods for the rabbit primary
enclosures. A facility representative stated the rabbit cages are occasionally flamed as well when they get extra dirty, but
this is not performed to every rabbit enclosure at least once every 30 days, it is just on an as needed basis. Primary
enclosures that are not sanitized properly and frequently may accumulate dust, fecal and urine waste products, and
bacterial/viral agents which may contribute to health issues in rabbits such as gastrointestinal and respiratory illness. All
primary enclosures for rabbits shall be sanitized at least once every 30 days in one of the following manners as
prescribed by 3.56(b)(3): washing with hot water (180F) and soap or detergent as in a mechanical cage washer, or by
washing all soiled surfaces with a detergent solution followed by a safe and effective disinfectant and rinse, or by cleaning
all soiled surfaces with live steam or flame. Correct by March 21, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.36(a) 
   
Annual report. 
The facility did not submit their fiscal year 2024 annual report to the Deputy Administrator on or before December 1 of 
calendar year 2024. At the time of inspection, the facility’s annual report had not yet been submitted. Timely submission of 
the annual report is essential to assure that professionally acceptable standards governing the care and use of animals 
were followed during the previous fiscal year. Each reporting facility shall submit an annual report, covering the use of live 
animals in the previous fiscal year, on or before December 1st of each calendar year. Correct by March 7, 2025. 
3.54(b) 
   
Feeding. 
The facility does not currently have a regular cleaning schedule for the food receptacles for their rabbits. The husbandry 
staff at the facility stated that there is no set schedule for the cleaning of the food receptacles, and that currently, the only 
time they are cleaned is when a new rabbit is put into a new cage. Unsanitary food receptacles can contaminate the food 
provided, and result in illness and disease in rabbits. All food receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitized at least once 
every 2 weeks. Correct by March 7, 2025. 
3.56(b)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility does not currently have a regular sanitization schedule for the primary enclosures for their rabbits. The rabbits 
are housed in mesh metal enclosures that are elevated above a trough used for urine and fecal waste removal. The 
husbandry staff stated that while the troughs are cleaned thoroughly once per day, the primary enclosures for the rabbits 
are only hosed down with water whenever they appear extra dirty. The husbandry staff stated that the hose does not 
output hot water. At the time of inspection, husbandry staff were not trained on sanitization methods for the rabbit primary 
enclosures. A facility representative stated the rabbit cages are occasionally flamed as well when they get extra dirty, but 
this is not performed to every rabbit enclosure at least once every 30 days, it is just on an as needed basis. Primary 
enclosures that are not sanitized properly and frequently may accumulate dust, fecal and urine waste products, and 
bacterial/viral agents which may contribute to health issues in rabbits such as gastrointestinal and respiratory illness. All 
primary enclosures for rabbits shall be sanitized at least once every 30 days in one of the following manners as 
prescribed by 3.56(b)(3): washing with hot water (180F) and soap or detergent as in a mechanical cage washer, or by

washing all soiled surfaces with a detergent solution followed by a safe and effective disinfectant and rinse, or by cleaning 
all soiled surfaces with live steam or flame. Correct by March 21, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
